newsitem.title: CHINA: China city sets auto exhaust rules to clean up air.
newsitem.headline: China city sets auto exhaust rules to clean up air.

text.p: The industrial city of Chongqing in southwest China will ban vehicles that fail to meet emission standards in a bid to curb worsening air pollution, the China Daily said on Thursday.
Authorities issued regulations requiring all vehicles to pass an exhaust emissions test before being allowed on the city's streets, it said.
Drivers who violated the new rules would have their licences suspended, it said.
The regulations, effective from September 10, also required all new vehicles produced in the city to pass an emissions test before being sold, it said.

Chongqing, one of China's largest and most polluted cities, is struggling to improve air quality as the number of cars and trucks on its roads surges. The number of vehicles in Chongqing climbed to 180,000 last year from 100,000 in 1990.
Shanghai's environmental bureau ruled in June that all vehicles would have to install catalytic converters to reduce exhaust emissions.

Ford Motor Co of the United States on Friday announced that it would sign an agreement with two Chinese government agencies for a $3.0 million project to develop oxidation catalysts as part of auto emission control efforts.

A team of Chinese and U.S. technical specialists recently recommended that China's auto industry concentrate on upgrading petrol, promoting small diesel engines and "clean fuels" such as compressed natural gas, and controlling exhaust emissions.
